threads.com:
It has been 5 months or 6 since AI became a thing in everyone's mouth with DALL-E mini and personally (as someone who consooms art and is not an artist) I haven't noticed a lot of changes in the art community, even when AIs like StableDiffusion have fixed most of its problems in less than 2 months.
Every artist I follow keeps receiving commissions and closing in minutes, they keep earning thousands on Patreon and the engagement has been pretty much the same as how things were a year ago, if not better.
I have noticed most artists I follow started to only post their work on Twitter while abandoning pages like Pixiv, FurAffinity, eHentai and other ones we all know due to the immense amount of spam that's in there, heck, even I as a consoomer I stopped using Pixiv, it became an unsearchble sea of untagged mess and I can't fucking jerk off anymore without digging like crazy for 5+ minutes in order to find the shit I actually like and not a sea of deformed victorian smug sluts.

If you ask me I feel AI is not going to affect freelancing in a lot of ways, however, when it comes to work in the industry I can say I've already seen some changes, like the use of AI for voice acting or AI used to design prints for shirts to be massproduced.
How do you see things? We're close to the end of the year.

>>6383839
Not me specifically, I’m talking about human artists in general. AI is bad for production not because the result is bad, but because it’s unpredictable, randomness is part of its core.

Even if a human can’t perfectly draw something, the intention can be clear enough. If AI was made more as a helping tool instead of an automation, it could be used more efficiently by artists. Right now it’s just a fun app for non artists play around generating random art.

Think about 3d art, you have full control over it, the pose, camera angle, depth of field, textures, materials, lights, you control everything, but the rendering is done by the computer.

last_replies.com: Mid-key, few jumps in value and saturation. Liberal use of fresnel effect and atmospheric perspective on skin, as well as very selective with detail to mimic eyesight. The examples you posted as falling short don't quite model form as well, they are too uniformly detailed and saturated.

If you are a /beg/inner or /int/ermediate in art, please use this thread to post pieces for critique or ask for advice.
Use this thread instead of making new threads or post in the drawthread with fundamental exercises.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:
1. screenshot the image and post that instead
2. change camera capture settings to something smaller
3. send to computer and resize in MSPaint

Read the sticky

TRY TO BE ACTIVE AND GIVE PEOPLE SOME FEEDBACK.

>>6383027

last_replies.com:

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6383027
Short answer is that they consider the behavior of the light relative to the forms of the objects and mechanisms of what captured the image.

Long answer:
You take the three dimensional shape of what you're painting and relate it to the position of your light source(s). A plane that is directly angled towards the light source will catch more light and be perceived by the human eye as brighter. If that plane has a gradual curve making it less directed towards the light it will gradually catch less light. This is one of the causes of soft edges.
There are many other factors like cast shadows having progressively less hard edges the further away from the object obstructing the light. Another consideration is the aperture and focal length of the object used or mimicked to capture the image.

On top of all the technical considerations you have the artistic perspective where you bend or break the rules for a specific desired effect.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
This thread is dedicated to master studies, where you copy artwork you admire as a form of study. They are the quickest way to improve and learn about any fundamental you are having problems with. If you need to work on your hands, copy hands from other artists, and if you're having trouble with rendering, make careful studies of paintings with lighting you admire. Studies can be quick or long. You can even copy anatomy books like Bridgman, Morpho, and Hogarth. The type of studies you want to do depend on your personal goals and the types of problems you are grappling with.

Artists of all levels are welcome. Critiques and redlines are encouraged.

>>6379333
>>6379414
>>6379427
Ive posted a few examples of trees with inking focus. Different styles and ways of rendering. Even the most simplified rendering shows attention to detail in their lines. The pines arent scribbled. The leaves arent just random swirls. They have line weights and contrasts. Light isnt uniform thorughout a tree and entire piece either (yours is all from the right and never reflects how other trees or the tree itself should affect lighting). These arent meant to be do it like this either or be this good right now. Just examples for future reference and to show the difference in controlled lines that you htought about vs 'get it done' mentality.

Also note some of these how dark it gets vs use of light. Yours is relatively uniform - black trunks, light leaves, very dark pines. Basically doing edge work. Take the first image - the black trunks in foreground really draw the eye. THe very light center line. The second image is similar - the very dark rendering of shadows dilineated from the rendering of bark. You can tell the bark is dark, but the shadows really pop. Value studies are very important when planning out ink. Ive done literal horus of inking and then realized ive overinked or the values are just fucked and had to start over. Thats before even considering bad lines or anything. Just clearly see value problems. Yours is relatively uniform blacks across. If you are intending to color, this isnt necessarily bad i guess, but for an inked piece, you wont have colors to save the values/it isnt just line art type of deal.

I recommend trying to do just a single branch or replicate a style you want - literally save it, fade it out or blue line it and print it off. Ink the blue lined art of said piece. Try to see the line he made and make it - its likely not just a random line thrown without thought.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6379333
>>6379414
>>6379427
>>6379441
This is an inked piece thats probably in line with what you were attempting. It is relatively simple with weak line work. Cabin not particularly good. But the piece comes together with lines. Youll see different renderings of even the simple background trees/trunks. They arent all identical in left to right values. Theres variety. The grass and brush is just thrown lines and some implied flowers or whatever with circles, etc. But the lines arent just up and down/all angled one way. There's values between the lines in some cases.

Compare some of this amateur piece to yours - even with how rushed this example looks, consider how their tall grass looks to yours. Both are very similar pieces thematically. Scribbles and simplified inking. I believe this is the effect you were going for, but you arent even taking the time this guy did. The lines on yours scream you just scribbled upa nd down in many places. With more care, you can achieve similar effects even 'rushing' like this final example has.

Inking is meticulous and time consuming work. Shortcuts are easily apparent on anyone taking a close examination of it and with any knowledge of the medium. We also see and appreciate that level of effort put in. We see a section of grass and know you spent like 5 hours doing it. We know that tree took you all day. We know the piece took you days to complete. We also know when it took you an hour.

If you want a serious artist workstation:

Or Ryzen 7950X or i9-13900K (i7-13700K if on a budget)

Ram: minimum 32gb (2x16gb). (Don't worry about DDR5 unless you bought a new gen ryzen, in which case your hand is forced.)

GPU: used 3090Ti (consider a 4090 if you don't care about having your wallet raped)

Storage: Make sure you get a TLC NVMe drive, preferably two. Choose from: Kingston KC3000, Crucial P5 Plus, WD Black SN770/SN850, Seagate Firecuda 530, Samsung 980/990 Pro. Install your OS on one drive, and use the other for cache.

Monitor: LG C2 42" OLED TV: technically a TV, but this is by far the best display available.

Why you should not trust youtube shills:

>I'm thinking of getting the Wacom One, should I buy it?
Fuck off retard. Ask a better question.

Recommended tablets:

>Intuos 3
Best screenless tablet. Look for one on Craigslist or Ebay.
>Intuos 4, 5 & Pro
Also good options. Will burn through your nibs.
>Samsung Galaxy Tab S6 Lite
Budget portable display tablet. Very solid drawing experience with Wacom EMR tech, but a small 10.4" display area.
>Used iPad Pro 2nd Gen 12.9"
Best option for a display tablet.
>Galaxy Tab S7+/S8+
Good premium alternative to an iPad Pro
>One by Wacom (not Wacom One)
Solid cheap option

Avoid:

>XP-Pen, Huion, Gaomon and every other Chinese brand
Poor build quality, lackluster pens, broken tilt, struggles to register light pressure, horrible customer support and the displays are not calibrated. All Chinese brands have the same problems. Check out the webm to understand how bad they are. Also watch out, Chinese companies shill HARD on /ic/; they do a lot of samefagging and frequently hurl personal insults.

>Microsoft Surface Pro
The N-Trig digitizer means you will always get wobbly lines.

>Lenovo
Bad drawing performance because they're not designed with art in mind.

>iPads (brand new) - Bad value
>iMacs and Macbooks - Never buy this garbage under any circumstance. It's a locked ecosystem with rubbish hardware you can't upgrade.

>>6377718

>The point is that I don't want to do that because copying I don't learn.
Another method is to draw a copy. Then hide the copy and the reference and then draw it again, from memory. "Active recall"

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: David Finch has a video called "how to reference other artists the right way" that you might find helpful

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6377705
Unironically, copy the homework but make slight changes.
Draw what you see in the ref, but add something different at a few parts.
For example, tilt the head or use different hand gestures.
Use additional refs if you have trouble imagining something not in the original ref.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6377712
>copying I don't learn.
ngmi

I've learned more from studying refs, watching artists draw live on Twitch and imitating them and following along timelapse videos on YouTube at 0.5x speed than from reading 10 books or just making shit up as I go.

The point is to actually integrate what you're learning into your next work. For example: say you want to study a really cool photo ref that you like. You do the thing, and notice while drawing it that you need to solve a certain amount of problems using the tools at your disposal to get the result you like.

Then, next time when you're drawing another thing (another study, or your own thing, or a commission, or just something fun) you apply the same logic that you did when you copied the thing.

It's about building an arsenal of technical and practical knowledge and honing it to the edge, and then using that to your advantage in order to exploit your own imagination.

In my opinion, creativity without technical prowess is pretty pictures.

Creativity with technical prowess is sublime.
